isis.stitle: ANTILOCK AIR BRAKE SYSTEM: BENDIX - MAINTENANCE AND SERVICE CHECKS - AR-1 ANTILOCK RELAY VALVE

svcsubproc.title: General
svcsubproc.para: Perform the tests and inspections presented at the prescribed intervals. If the AR-1 fails to function as described, or leakage is excessive, it should be repaired or replaced. Use only International approved parts.

svcsubproc.title: Every 3 Months, 25,000 Miles or 900 Operating Hours

step1.para: Remove any accumulated contaminants and visually inspect the exterior for excessive corrosion and physical damage.
Inspect all air lines connected to the AR-1 for signs of wear or physical damage. Replace as necessary.
Test air line fittings for excessive leakage and tighten or replace as necessary.
Perform the Leakage Test described below.

svcsubproc.title: Every Year, 100,000 Miles, or 3,600 Operating Hours
svcsubproc.para: Perform the Operation and Leakage Tests that follow.

svcsubproc.title: AR-1 Antilock Relay Valve Operation Test

step1.para: Apply and release the brakes several times while an observer is checking for prompt application and release at each wheel. If prompt reaction is noted at some, but not all wheels, test the antilock modulator between the AR-1 and the brake actuator for proper operation. If a "sluggish" response is noted at all wheels, inspect for a kinked or obstructed air line leading to or from the AR-1.

If a complete release of the brakes is noted at some, but not all wheels, test the antilock modulator between the AR-1 and the brake actuator for proper operation. If an incomplete release is noted at all wheels, inspect for a kinked or obstructed air line leading to or from the AR-1.

During brake release, confirm that a slight "puff" of air exits at the AR-1's quick exhaust port in the cover. Air exiting at this exhaust port indicates the AR-1 integral quick release is functioning.

svcsubproc.title: AR-1 Antilock Relay Valve Leakage Test

step1.para: Build the air system pressure to governor cut-out, and apply a soap solution to the exhaust port in body. The leakage noted should not exceed a one-inch bubble in less than three (3) seconds.

Make and hold a full brake application and apply a soap solution to the exhaust ports in the body, cover, and around the cover where it joins the body. The leakage noted should not exceed a one-inch bubble in less than three (3) seconds at any exhaust port.
Park the vehicle on a level surface and block the wheels and/or hold the vehicle by means other than the air brakes.
Drain the air pressure from all vehicle reservoirs.
Identify, mark or label all air lines and wiring cables and their respective connections on the CR-15 Relay Valve/EC-15 Controller to facilitate ease of installation.

note.para: Always turn key switch to OFF position before disconnecting any portion of the antilock wiring system. If circuits are disconnected with the key ON, the EC-15 controller will record the open circuit as a fault condition.

step1.para: Disconnect all air lines and wiring.

Note and mark the mounting position of the relay valve/controller assembly on the vehicle. Remove and save the relay valve/controller mounting hardware, then remove the CR-15 Relay Valve/EC-15 Controller assembly from the vehicle.
Remove all contaminants from the exterior of the relay valve/controller assembly, making sure to keep all contaminants from entering the open ports on the assembly.

Note and mark the position of the EC-15 controller relative to the AR-1 relay valve for later reassembly. Remove the 4 capscrews securing the controller to the relay valve. Carefully separate the controller from the relay valve, making sure not to damage the gasket between the 2 components, if possible. Peel the gasket from the EC-15 or AR-1 and retain for use if it is not damaged. (NOTE: Use a new gasket if the old gasket is damaged or if a new gasket is readily available.)

note.para: For disassembly of the relay valve, refer to GROUP 04 - BRAKES.

step1.para: After noting the relationship of the positioning marks made in Step 7 of Removal, above, position the gasket on the EC-15, then secure the EC-15 to the AR-1 antilock relay valve using the 4 capscrews. Torque the capscrews to 50-80 Lb. In. (5.6-9.0 Nm).
Install all air line fittings and plugs (as marked during removal) making certain thread sealing material does not enter the valve.
Install the assembled CR-15 Relay Valve/EC-15 Controller on the vehicle in the position marked during Step 5 of Removal, above.
Connect all air lines and wiring cables to the valve and controller assembly using the identification made during Valve Removal Step 3, above.
After installing the valve and controller assembly, test all air fittings for excessive leakage and tighten as needed.
